central_thesis: The "Scroll of Set - April 1997" offers a multifaceted exploration of Setian philosophy and practical magic, emphasizing individual initiatory evolution through concepts like Xeper, Remanifestation, and Progress. It contextualizes these principles within broader esoteric traditions (e.g., LHP Yoga, alchemy), addresses community identity and challenges, and provides updates on resources and collective workings, all aimed at conscious self-development and the manifestation of True Will.

structure_content.summary: This article defines 'Progress' as a V° Word unique to Setian initiation, distinct from its mundane meaning. It is presented as the 'alchemy of Xeper viz. Xeper,' functioning as an impelling force for the Initiate's mind towards Remanifestation, an initiatory fire generated by Xeper, and a focus on the 'Fonic universe.' Progress clarifies the complex initiatory nexus of Xeper, encourages exploration, provides direction, counters inertia, and inspires charting unknown existential possibilities. It is understood as being born from Xeper and Remanifestation, symbolizing a link to individual, personal divinity.

This section explains 'Xem,' originally meaning 'black earth' or a 'sacred place.' In its Setian context, as formulated by Magus Ronald K. Barrett, Xem refers to a 'focusing' of Xeper or 'narrowing a direction.' It is also interpreted as 'the transmutation of the base into the pure,' signifying it as an aspect of the Æon of Set, aligning with the alchemical tradition.
This brief section lists individuals who have achieved various degrees or recognitions within the Temple of Set, acknowledging their advancements in their initiatory paths.

This article elaborates on Magister d'Merlin's concept of 'Progress' as the sustained momentum of the initiatory journey. It is the force that carries an Initiate through long, challenging periods between significant milestones like Xeper, Remanifestation, Runa, and Essent. Progress instills an appreciation for the distance traveled, cultivates grim determination, and maintains focus on fundamental initiatory questions, thereby encompassing the continuous and unending nature of the Setian path.

This article addresses the internal debate within the Temple of Set regarding its identity, specifically questioning whether it should be labeled 'Satanic.' It concludes that the Temple is fundamentally unique, nonconforming, and resistant to static definitions, mirroring the nature of Set himself. The author encourages members to accept disagreement and move beyond the need for rigid, unyielding definitions.

structure_content.chapter_title: House of Thoth, Occult Institute of Technology Website, Order of Setne Khamuast Website, Temple of Set Online Bookstore
structure_content.summary: These sections provide updates on administrative and resource aspects of the Temple of Set, including a book-search service (House of Thoth), new web addresses for the Occult Institute of Technology and the Order of Setne Khamuast, and the establishment of the Temple of Set Online Bookstore, aiming to improve accessibility to Setian materials and facilitate communication.

This article announces a collective MetaMind Element working scheduled for May 1997. Its objectives are to strengthen individual 'metamental' energies, collectively create a designated 'location' for the Element, and establish a permanent, accessible home for it for all Setians. This initiative is described as a cooperative Setian experiment operating under the auspices of the Order of the Vampyre.

This piece explores Bes, an Egyptian neter, depicted as a misfit god associated with indulgence, fun, and protection. The author shares personal experiences of working with Bes, noting it helps in confronting fears, overcoming introversion, becoming comfortable in diverse social settings, and using the 'Black Magic mirror of truth' for self-assessment. Bes is also suggested as the patron of the 'Age of Satan,' embodying a rebellious, iconoclastic nature.

structure_content.chapter_title: Myth and Meaning in the Age of the Intranet
structure_content.summary: This article introduces the Temple of Set's new secure Intranet website, http://www.xeper.org, designed to make Setian documents more accessible. It outlines the procedure for obtaining access and highlights the Intranet's role in supporting the Temple's growth as a trans-national entity and fostering communication among members.

This article discusses an alleged Satanic worship case involving Egyptian youths, advising Setians traveling to Egypt to exercise extreme caution. It recommends pre-researching local laws, avoiding Setian/Satanic items, and being discreet in conversations. The incident is contextualized within Egyptian society’s struggle to bridge cultural gaps while entering the global village.

This section introduces LHP-oriented Yoga as a method for conscious self-development, aiming to reach the 'essence' and actualize one's full potential, distinct from conventional RHP interpretations. It defines Yoga as 'union' (analogous to a 'magical link') and outlines its eight limbs (Yama, Niyama, Asana, Pranayama, Pratyahara, Dharana, Dhyana, Samadhi) from a Left Hand Path perspective, emphasizing individual will and experience. Various types of Yoga are also mentioned.

structure_content.chapter_title: Musings on my Time as a Setian
structure_content.summary: This personal reflection details the author's initiatory journey, emphasizing Remanifestation as a continuous process of shedding old personality aspects ('dried husks') and embracing new ones ('shiny pink flesh'). It highlights the development of detachment alongside compassion for creation and destruction, portraying the journey as a cycle of learning, transformation, and perpetual self-discovery driven by an inner 'need-fire' and 'flood' of desire.

This column offers music recommendations, including artists like The Hellecasters, Deuter, the Xena soundtrack, and Corsican folk music. It suggests these selections as suitable aids for magical workings or for evoking specific moods, placing them within a cultural and esoteric context.

This article recounts the transformation of the Order of the Python into the Order of Uart. Inspired by the author's 'Heka-An' work (combining magical visualization with art), the term 'uart' is reinterpreted to mean 'serpent,' 'well of the flame,' or 'a place of bifurcation.' This transformation signifies the rebirth of the Order from its past, with a new focus on 'Nine Perceptions' and the creation of artifacts to preserve and transmit the Temple's history and culture.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Question of Religion vs. Spirituality
structure_content.summary: This article distinguishes magic from conventional religion, asserting magic as an art for personal growth and attaining higher consciousness, not inherently evil. It defines 'religion' as uniting man with god and 'magic' as uniting mental/spiritual aspects for godhood realization. The author argues against religious codes that limit experience, advocating instead for the exploration of the subjective universe to uncover truth beyond ordinary imagination.

This article discusses two forms of magical power: 'power-over' and 'power-to.' It criticizes the use of 'power-over' others, especially Setians without consent, but acknowledges legitimate societal applications. The primary focus is on 'power-over' oneself (disciplining the personality) and the enhancement of 'power-to' (creativity and true will manifestation). A three-step process is outlined: Greater Black Magic (GBM) for Xeper, Will for Remanifestation, and increased capacity for 'power-to' through creative expression.

structure_content.chapter_title: And You Thought It Was Just a Chance to Drink Some German Beer ...
structure_content.summary: This article urges Setians to attend international Conclaves, framing them as religious festivals and vital opportunities for spiritual growth. It emphasizes that participation helps overcome inertia, deepens initiation, and contributes to the Temple's 'puissance and dominion,' advocating for active engagement to further Setian purpose.

This article offers a Setian interpretation of Ragnarök, viewing it not as a literal apocalypse but as a symbolic process of personal initiation on the Left-Hand Path. It signifies the destruction of old belief systems ('Old Gods') and the birth of new self-gods, leading to a continuous battle of self-creation and the reshaping of the world to align with one's will, directly linking it to the ongoing processes of Xeper and Remanifestation.

structure_content.chapter_title: Found in our Local Church Bulletin
structure_content.summary: This section contains humorous, mundane excerpts from a local church bulletin, providing a contrast to the esoteric themes of the other articles.

This article describes the 'Xepera Mundi' working, designed by Adept Aaron Besson, with four specific magical objectives: awakening potential Setians, revealing enemies' weak spots, enhancing Pylon members' good fortune, and increasing interaction between Pylons. The author details personal involvement and related activities, including lectures and video interviews, showcasing a collective magical effort.

This section clarifies that the Temple of Set is not 'Satanic' in the conventional sense, distinguishing it from problematic groups. It recommends specific LHP texts (e.g., 'Zephyr,' 'Sacred Drift') for those interested in esoteric Satanism and its historical connections, particularly the 'Dark Light' as a symbol of individuality. The article also emphasizes the Setian's need to master when to speak, teach, or keep silent, and the nature of true 'occult' (hidden) knowledge.

key_concepts.definition: The 'alchemy of Xeper viz. Xeper'; an impelling force for the Initiate's mind towards Xeper and Remanifestation; the initiatory fire/force from Xeper; a focus on the 'Fonic universe'; the drive and momentum in the initiatory journey; a symbol of personal divinity, rooted in the monarch's progression throughout the realm.

The core Setian philosophy and practice, meaning 'to Come Into Being.' It is a metamorphic process of self-creation, often described as a lustrous sapphire with many facets. Its Egyptian root KLP means 'to pass on, change, come anew, to sprout, exchange, succeed,' signifying continuous movement and transformation.

The metamorphic process of Xeper; dynamically prepared in this incarnation, involving the integration of experiences, establishing continuity, and Becoming something more than one was before. It is a death/rebirth process of personality transformation, essential for effective initiatory evolution.

Originally 'black earth' or 'the Black Land,' also referring to a 'sacred or holy place.' In a Setian context (as defined by Magus Ronald K. Barrett), it means 'focusing' of Xeper or 'narrowing a direction.' It is also interpreted as 'the transmutation of the base into the pure,' signifying an aspect of the Æon of Set.

A conceptual 'point of embarkation for additional adventures' that follows Remanifestation. It is described as an 'omnidirectional' mystery that does not incorporate a polarity, suggesting open-ended future exploration.
The fundamental 'essence' or initial reason for embarking on the initiatory journey, a foundational principle of self-discovery.
The conceptual realm upon which Setian Progress causes the Initiate to focus, distinct from the mundane or objective universe, guiding the mind towards esoteric understanding.
The visualizing principle in magic, an imaginative faculty crucial for manifesting change and creating subjective reality.

A new Order transformed from the Order of the Python. The term 'uart' means 'serpent,' 'well of the flame,' or 'a place of bifurcation'/'division.' It symbolizes the rebirth of the Order, focusing on 'Nine Perceptions' and the creation of artifacts to preserve Temple history and culture.

Magical influence or control exerted on others. It is generally criticized within Setian ethics, especially without express consent, but acknowledged as legitimate in specific societal roles (e.g., traffic control, parenting).
Creativity; the ability to manifest one's true will, achieve desired outcomes, and expand one's capacity. It is an enhancement of personal capability resulting from self-mastery.

A concept illustrating that working with certain neters (e.g., Bes) or engaging in deep self-reflection forces an individual to confront their authentic self, revealing what truly 'is' rather than what one wishes to perceive or be perceived as.

Not a literal end-of-the-world scenario, but a symbolic process of personal initiation and transformation on the Left-Hand Path. It signifies the destruction of old belief systems ('Old Gods') and the birth of new self-gods, leading to a continuous battle of self-creation and the re-shaping of the world to align with one's will, inextricably linked to Xeper and Remanifestation.

A method for conscious self-development, distinct from RHP interpretations, aiming for 'union of the whole being' according to one's true will. It encompasses eight limbs (Yama, Niyama, Asana, Pranayama, Pratyahara, Dharana, Dhyana, Samadhi) interpreted through an LHP lens, emphasizing individual experience and autonomy.

'Hidden' knowledge that is not mass-produced, easily accessible, or conventional. It is gained through direct experience, specific insights, or personal discovery, and its power is inversely proportional to its widespread availability.
One of the three cults opposing Setians, teaching that being smart is bad and excluding individuals concerned with Mysteries, thereby fostering intellectual mediocrity.

One of the three cults opposing Setians, teaching an idealized, narrow form for life (e.g., traditional family structure, suburban living) and claiming ownership over an individual's choices and body.

One of the three cults opposing Setians, teaching that suffering leads to redemption, hijacking social empowerment movements by replacing power-seeking with pleas for justice, and enabling individuals to engage in poor behavior under the guise of past injury or 'abuse'.

practical_system.description: The text outlines a dynamic system of individual initiatory evolution rooted in Setian philosophy. It centers on the conscious application of Xeper (Coming Into Being), Remanifestation (the metamorphic process of continuous self-creation), and Progress (the alchemical drive that propels and sustains this evolution). The system emphasizes rigorous self-development, the disciplined pursuit of 'power-to' through creative expression and True Will, and the acquisition and strategic application of 'occult' (hidden) knowledge. It also describes collective magical workings (MetaMind, Xepera Mundi) and the structural evolution of magical orders (e.g., Uart), demonstrating both individual and communal approaches to Setian magic. The underlying principle is to continuously transform the self and reshape the surrounding world to align with one's awakened will.
tools: Conceptual words and V° Words (e.g., Progress, Xem, Xeper, Remanifestation, Runa, Essent) as foci for conscious work and understanding.
Magical diary or 'victory book' for recording triumphs over the Cults of Stupidity, Conventionality, and the Victim.
'Black Magic mirror of truth' for rigorous self-assessment and confrontation.
LHP-oriented Yoga techniques for physical, mental, and spiritual discipline and expansion.
Skills of concentration, visualization, and focused willpower for magical operations.
Temple Intranet (http://www.xeper.org) for accessing esoteric documents and fostering transnational communication.
Curated musical selections (e.g., from 'From the Well of Pythia') to enhance magical workings and evoke specific moods.
Creation of artifacts as physical embodiments and transmitters of Setian history, culture, and initiatory knowledge.
rituals: Individual initiatory evolution through conscious application of Xeper, Remanifestation, and Progress.
Working with specific neters (e.g., Bes) for self-confrontation, overcoming personal limitations, and expanding awareness.
MetaMind Element working: a collective endeavor for strengthening individual 'metamental' energies, creating a 'location' for the Element, and establishing its permanent home.
Xepera Mundi working: a collective ritual designed to awaken potential Setians, reveal enemy weak spots, enhance Pylon members' good fortune, and increase Pylon interaction.
Uart working: a ritual focused on integrating 'Nine Perceptions' and creating 'artifacts' to embody and transmit the history and culture of the Temple of Set.

LHP-oriented Yoga practices: methods for conscious self-development, involving the eight limbs (Yama, Niyama, Asana, Pranayama, Pratyahara, Dharana, Dhyana, Samadhi) interpreted through an individualistic, Left Hand Path lens.
Application of Greater Black Magic (GBM) for 'power-over' oneself (disciplining personality) and enhancing 'power-to' (manifesting True Will and creativity).
Cultivation of mental alchemy to realize Xeper and focus on the 'Fonic universe'.

relevant_quotes.text: Progress is born of Xeper and Remanifestation.
The facet of Progress is best described as the 'alchemy of Xeper viz. Xeper'.
In its V° Word sense, Progress should not be interpreted as identical with the ordinary concept of 'progress'.
In Uttering Xeper Magus Aquino brought the Eon of Set into being. Xeper itself has many facets to it and I will use my favorite analogy of it as a lustrous sapphire in its complete form.
The phenomenon of Progress is that the Initiate's mind is expanded and given a drive towards the vision of Xeper, the metamorphic process of Remanifestation.
In a literal translation, Progress would signify the 'perpetual and eternal recreation of the self' aspect of Xeper.
In its original sense as formulated by Magus Ronald K. Barrett, Xem referred to a 'focusing' of Xeper.
Progress is the agitating force that counters any tendency to inertia.
Every Setian has the potential of neter-hood. [One of my favorite aphorisms: 'As we are now, Set once was; and as Set is now, we will Become.']
What is alchemy? It is 'the transmutation of the base into the pure', and this is where Xem can be interpreted as an aspect of the Æon of Set.
Set was the neter who was 'different' from the others.
It's Xeper, the core of the Temple's philosophy and practice.

As we manage to integrate the sights, sounds, and experiences of the journey into ourselves, establishing a sense of continuity between them and Becoming something more than we were before, we call that Remanifestation.

The Wolf has been set free. He has run loose for a long time now. Ragnarök has begun. But it is at its end. The Old Gods are all dead, and the world is destroyed. A new world and new gods have been born from the ashes of the old. This, I discovered, has happened during my initiation.
The Egyptian verb Xeper is comparable to the Hebrew word KLP (Keth, Lamed, Pe).

The Temple of Set is opposed by three powerful cults. These cults are pervasive, merciless, and untiring. They must be fought in all of their manifestations. Their names are the Cult of Stupidity, the Cult of Conventionality, and the Cult of the Victim.
The Setian must create and see justice.
“Occult” means “hidden”. That means that you won’t find occult knowledge conveniently packaged in mass-produced books.
The Setian must learn when to speak and share, when to teach and when to keep silent. He must also learn that real secrets seldom look like the keys of the universe to the profane.

Yoga means “union”. In the mind of a pious person, the inferiority complex which accounts for his piety compels him to interpret this emancipation as union with that gaseous vertebrate whom he has invented and called “God”.
In the highest sense Yoga means “union of the whole being”, or “synthesis of the whole being according to one’s true will”.

critical_analysis.relevance: The 'Scroll of Set - April 1997' offers a crucial snapshot of the Temple of Set's ongoing philosophical and practical development during a formative period. It deeply explores and elaborates on core Setian concepts such as Xeper and Remanifestation by introducing and defining new V° Words like Progress and Xem, providing nuanced interpretations essential for advanced Setian practice. The periodical also engages with critical internal discussions, such as the Temple's identity concerning 'Satanism,' and addresses external challenges posed by 'mundane' societal cults (Stupidity, Conventionality, Victim). Furthermore, it places Setian magical practice within a broader esoteric context, discussing LHP Yoga and historical alchemy. This collection is highly relevant for understanding the evolution of modern Left Hand Path philosophy, self-deification, and magical practice within a structured esoteric order, offering both theoretical depth and practical guidance for initiates.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience consists of Initiates of the Temple of Set, particularly those at higher degrees (IV°, V°). It is also highly relevant for advanced practitioners of Western Esotericism and Left Hand Path magic, scholars studying modern occultism and new religious movements, and individuals deeply interested in the practical application of self-deification, personal transformation, and structured magical systems. Some sections also cater to those seeking community updates and resources within the Temple of Set.
